MATH(BINF) 4780/6780.description: Mathematical models in the biological sciences, systems, phase-plane analysis, diffusion, convective transport, bifurcation analysis. Possible applications will include population models, infectious disease and epidemic models, acquired immunity and drug distribution, tumor growth, and analysis of arterial flow dynamics.

MATH 4790/6790.title: The Mathematics of Option Pricing
MATH 4790/6790.description: Bonds, stock markets, derivatives, arbitrage, and binomial tree models for stocks and options, Black-Scholes formula for options pricing, hedging. Computational methods will be incorporated.

MATH 4801.title: Mathematics Internship
MATH 4801.description: Students are permitted to enter an organization to obtain practical and applied experience. A paper describing and analyzing this experience is required.

MATH 4802/6802.title: Industrial Mathematics
MATH 4802/6802.description: Students apply mathematical problem solving to complete an industry project.

MATH 4850/6850.title: History of Mathematics
MATH 4850/6850.description: The development of mathematical thought from ancient times to the present, paying particular attention to the context of today's mathematics curriculum.

MATH 4900/6900.title: Topics in Mathematics
MATH 4900/6900.description: A special topic not otherwise offered in the mathematics curriculum.

MATH 4950.title: Research in Mathematics
MATH 4950.description: Research in mathematics directed by a faculty member in the department of mathematics. A final report is required.

MATH 4960R.title: Faculty-Mentored Undergraduate Research I
MATH 4960R.description: Faculty-supervised independent or collaborative inquiry into fundamental and applied problems within a discipline that requires students to gather, analyze, and synthesize and interpret data and to present results in writing and other relevant communication formats.

MATH 4970R.title: Faculty-Mentored Undergraduate Research II
MATH 4970R.description: Faculty-supervised independent or collaborative inquiry into fundamental and applied problems within a discipline that requires students to gather, analyze, and synthesize and interpret data and to present results in writing and other relevant communication formats.

MATH 4980R.title: Faculty-Mentored Undergraduate Research III
MATH 4980R.description: Faculty-supervised independent or collaborative inquiry into fundamental and applied problems within a discipline that requires students to gather, analyze, synthesize, and interpret data and to present results in writing and other relevant communication formats.

MATH 4990R.title: Undergraduate Research Thesis (or Final Project)
MATH 4990R.description: Faculty-supervised independent or collaborative inquiry into fundamental and applied problems within a discipline that requires students to gather, analyze, and synthesize and interpret data. Students will write or produce a thesis or other professional capstone product, such as a report or portfolio that describes their systematic and in-depth inquiry.

MATH 5001W/7001W.title: Arithmetic and Problem Solving
MATH 5001W/7001W.description: Topics in mathematics designed for future elementary school teachers. Problem-solving. Number systems: whole numbers, integers, rational numbers (fractions), and real numbers (decimals), and the relationships between these systems. Understanding multiplication and division, including why standard computational algorithms work. Properties of arithmetic. Applications of elementary mathematics.

MATH(EMAT) 5001E.title: Arithmetic and Problem Solving
MATH(EMAT) 5001E.description: Topics in mathematics designed for future elementary school teachers. Problem-solving. Number systems: whole numbers, integers, rational numbers (fractions) and real numbers (decimals), and the relationships between these systems. Understanding multiplication and division, including why standard computational algorithms work. Properties of arithmetic. Applications of elementary mathematics.

MATH(EMAT) 5001/7001.title: Arithmetic and Problem Solving
MATH(EMAT) 5001/7001.description: Topics in mathematics designed for future elementary school teachers. Problem solving. Number systems: whole numbers, integers, rational numbers (fractions) and real numbers (decimals), and the relationships between these systems. Understanding multiplication and division, including why standard computational algorithms work. Properties of arithmetic. Applications of elementary mathematics.

MATH(EMAT) 5002/7002.title: Geometry and Problem Solving
MATH(EMAT) 5002/7002.description: A deep examination of mathematical topics designed for future elementary school teachers. Length, area, and volume. Geometric shapes and their properties. Probability. Elementary number theory. Applications of elementary mathematics.

MATH(EMAT) 5003/7003.title: Algebra and Problem Solving
MATH(EMAT) 5003/7003.description: A deep examination of topics in mathematics that are relevant for elementary school teaching. Probability, number theory, algebra and functions, including ratio and proportion. Posing and modifying problems.

MATH(EMAT) 5020/7020.title: Arithmetic for Middle Grades Teachers
MATH(EMAT) 5020/7020.description: A deep examination of topics in mathematics that are relevant for middle grades teachers. Reasoning about addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division within the base-ten system and with fractions. Deriving and explaining procedures and algorithms in arithmetic.

MATH 5030/7030.title: Geometry and Measurement for Middle Grades Teachers
MATH 5030/7030.description: Principles of geometry and measurement for middle school teachers.

MATH(EMAT) 5035/7035.title: Algebra for Middle Grades Teachers
MATH(EMAT) 5035/7035.description: A deep examination of topics in mathematics that are relevant for middle grades teachers. Reasoning about fraction division, ratio, proportional relationships, inversely proportional relationships, descriptive statistics, probability, factors, multiples, and prime numbers. Deriving and explaining equations and solution methods.

MATH 5200W/7200W.title: Foundations of Geometry I
MATH 5200W/7200W.description: Advanced elementary geometry for prospective teachers of secondary school mathematics: axiom systems and models; the parallel postulate; neutral, Euclidean, and non-Euclidean geometries.

MATH 5200/7200.title: Foundations of Geometry I
MATH 5200/7200.description: Advanced elementary geometry for prospective teachers of secondary school mathematics: axiom systems and models; the parallel postulate; neutral, Euclidean, and non-Euclidean geometries.

MATH 5210/7210.title: Foundations of Geometry II
MATH 5210/7210.description: Further development of the axioms and models for Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry; transformation geometry.

MATH 6800.title: Directed Reading and/or Projects
MATH 6800.description: Directed reading and/or project at the master's level.

MATH 7000.title: Master's Research
MATH 7000.description: Research while enrolled for a master's degree under the direction of faculty members.

MATH(EMAT) 7001E.title: Arithmetic and Problem Solving
MATH(EMAT) 7001E.description: Topics in mathematics designed for future elementary school teachers. Problem-solving. Number systems: whole numbers, integers, rational numbers (fractions) and real numbers (decimals), and the relationships between these systems. Understanding multiplication and division, including why standard computational algorithms work. Properties of arithmetic. Applications of elementary mathematics.

MATH 7005.title: Graduate Student Seminar
MATH 7005.description: Advanced supervised experience in an applied setting. This course may not be used to satisfy a student's approved program of study.

MATH 7040.title: Basic Ideas of Calculus I
MATH 7040.description: Survey of one-variable calculus in preparation for teaching calculus at the secondary level: combines review of basic techniques with careful study of underlying concepts.

MATH 7050.title: Basic Ideas of Calculus II
MATH 7050.description: A continuation of Basic Ideas of Calculus I focusing on functions of several variables.

MATH 7100.title: Technical Report
MATH 7100.description: For use with the Master's degree in Applied Mathematical Science - Mathematics option.

MATH 7300.title: Master's Thesis
MATH 7300.description: Thesis writing under the direction of the major professor.

MATH 7900.title: Foundations for Graduate Mathematics
MATH 7900.description: An intensive review of techniques and material essential for graduate study in mathematics, including background in calculus and linear algebra. Emphasis is on small group study and presentations. Topics include proofs, induction, the metric structure of the reals, the Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem, and the diagonalization theorem.

MATH 8000.title: Algebra I
MATH 8000.description: Groups and rings, including Sylow theorems, classifying small groups, finitely generated abelian groups, Jordan-Holder theorem, solvable groups, simplicity of the alternating group, euclidean domains, principal ideal domains, unique factorization domains, noetherian rings, Hilbert basis theorem, Zorn's lemma, and existence of maximal ideals and vector space bases.

MATH 8005.title: Problem Session in Algebra
MATH 8005.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in algebra as an aid to mastery of the basic theory.

MATH 8010.title: Algebra II
MATH 8010.description: Modules and fields, including noetherian modules, finitely generated modules over principal ideal domains, canonical forms of matrices, spectral theorems, tensor products, algebraic and transcendental field extensions, galois theory, solvability of polynomials, symmetric functions, cyclotomic extensions, finite fields, solution formulas for polynomials of low degree.

MATH 8020.title: Commutative Algebra
MATH 8020.description: Localization and completion, Nakayama's lemma, Dedekind domains, Hilbert's basis theorem, Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, Krull dimension, depth and Cohen-Macaulay rings, regular local rings.

MATH 8030.title: Topics in Algebra
MATH 8030.description: Topics in abstract algebra at the level of current research.

MATH 8040.title: Representation Theory of Finite Groups
MATH 8040.description: Irreducible and indecomposable representations, Schur's lemma, Maschke's theorem, the Wedderburn structure theorem, characters and orthogonality relations, induced representations and Frobenius reciprocity, central characters and central idempotents, Burnside's p^a q^b theorem, Frobenius normal p-complement theorem.

MATH 8080.title: Lie Algebras
MATH 8080.description: Nilpotent and solvable Lie algebras, structure and classification of semisimple Lie algebras, roots, weights, finite-dimensional representations.

MATH 8100.title: Real Analysis I
MATH 8100.description: Measure and integration theory with relevant examples from Lebesgue integration, Hilbert spaces (only with regard to L^2), L^p spaces and the related Riesz representation theorem. Hahn, Jordan and Lebesgue decomposition theorems, Radon-Nikodym Theorem and Fubini's Theorem.

MATH 8105.title: Problem Session in Real Analysis
MATH 8105.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in real analysis as an aid to mastery of basic theory.

MATH 8110.title: Real Analysis II
MATH 8110.description: Topics including: Haar Integral, change of variable formula, Hahn-Banach theorem for Hilbert spaces, Banach spaces and Fourier theory (series, transform, Gelfand-Fourier homomorphism).

MATH 8130.title: Topics in Analysis
MATH 8130.description: Topics in analysis at the level of current research.

MATH 8150.title: Complex Variables I
MATH 8150.description: The Cauchy-Riemann Equations, linear fractional transformations and elementary conformal mappings, Cauchy's theorems and its consequences, including Morera's theorem, Taylor and Laurent expansions, maximum principle, residue theorem, argument principle, Rouche's theorem and Liouville's theorem.

MATH 8155.title: Problem Session in Complex Analysis
MATH 8155.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in complex analysis as an aid to mastery of the basic theory.

MATH 8160.title: Complex Variables II
MATH 8160.description: Topics including Riemann Mapping Theorem, elliptic functions, Mittag-Leffler and Weierstrass Theorems, analytic continuation and Riemann surfaces.

MATH 8170.title: Functional Analysis I
MATH 8170.description: Hilbert spaces and Banach spaces, spectral theory, topological vector spaces, convexity and its consequences, including the Krein-Milman theorem.

MATH 8190.title: Lie Groups
MATH 8190.description: Classical groups, exponential map, Poincare-Birkhoff-Witt Theorem, homogeneous spaces, adjoint representation, covering groups, compact groups, Peter-Weyl Theorem, Weyl character formula.

MATH 8200.title: Algebraic Topology
MATH 8200.description: The fundamental group, van Kampen's theorem, and covering spaces. Introduction to homology: simplicial, singular, and cellular. Applications.

MATH 8205.title: Problem Session in Topology
MATH 8205.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in topology as an aid to mastery of the basic theory.

MATH 8210.title: Topology of Manifolds
MATH 8210.description: Poincare duality, deRham's theorem, topics from differential topology.

MATH 8230.title: Topics in Topology and Geometry
MATH 8230.description: Advanced topics in topology and/or differential geometry leading to and including research level material.

MATH 8250.title: Differential Geometry I
MATH 8250.description: Differentiable manifolds, vector bundles, tensors, flows, and Frobenius' theorem. Introduction to Riemannian geometry.

MATH 8260.title: Differential Geometry II
MATH 8260.description: Riemannian geometry: connections, curvature, first and second variation; geometry of submanifolds. Gauss-Bonnet theorem. Additional topics, such as characteristic classes, complex manifolds, integral geometry.

MATH 8300.title: Introduction to Algebraic Geometry
MATH 8300.description: An invitation to algebraic geometry through a study of examples. Affine and projective varieties, regular and rational maps, Nullstellensatz. Veronese and Segre varieties, Grassmannians, algebraic groups, quadrics. Smoothness and tangent spaces, singularities and tangent cones.

MATH 8310.title: Geometry of Schemes
MATH 8310.description: The language of Grothendieck's theory of schemes. Topics include the spectrum of a ring, "gluing" spectra to form schemes, products, quasi-coherent sheaves of ideals, and the functor of points.

MATH 8315.title: Sheaves and Cohomology
MATH 8315.description: Main results and techniques for sheaves on topological spaces and their cohomology.

MATH 8320.title: Algebraic Curves
MATH 8320.description: The theory of curves, including linear series and the Riemann Roch theorem. Either the algebraic (variety), arithmetic (function field), or analytic (Riemann surface) aspect of the subject may be emphasized in different years.

MATH 8330.title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry
MATH 8330.description: Advanced topics such as algebraic surfaces, or cohomology and sheaves.

MATH 8400.title: Algebraic/Analytic Number Theory I
MATH 8400.description: The core material of algebraic number theory: number fields, rings of integers, discriminants, ideal class groups, Dirichlet's unit theorem, splitting of primes; p-adic fields, Hensel's lemma, adeles and ideles, the strong approximation theorem.

MATH 8410.title: Algebraic/Analytic Number Theory II
MATH 8410.description: A continuation of Algebraic and Analytic Number Theory I, introducing analytic methods: the Riemann Zeta function, its analytic continuation and functional equation, the Prime number theorem; sieves, the Bombieri-Vinogradov theorem, the Chebotarev density theorem.

MATH 8430.title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry
MATH 8430.description: Topics in Algebraic number theory and Arithmetic geometry, such as class field theory, Iwasawa theory, elliptic curves, complex multiplication, cohomology theories, Arakelov theory, diophantine geometry, automorphic forms, L-functions, representation theory.

MATH 8440.title: Topics in Combinatorial/Analytic Number Theory
MATH 8440.description: Topics in combinatorial and analytic number theory, such as sieve methods, probabilistic models of prime numbers, the distribution of arithmetic functions, the circle method, additive number theory, transcendence methods.

MATH 8500.title: Advanced Numerical Analysis I
MATH 8500.description: Numerical solution of nonlinear equations in one and several variables, numerical methods for constrained and unconstrained optimization, numerical solution of linear systems, numerical methods for computing eigenvalues and eigenvectors, numerical solution of linear least squares problems, computer applications for applied problems.

MATH 8505.title: Problem Session in Numerical Analysis
MATH 8505.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in numerical analysis as an aid to mastery of the basic theory.

MATH 8510.title: Advanced Numerical Analysis II
MATH 8510.description: Polynomial and spline interpolation and approximation theory, numerical integration methods, numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, computer applications for applied problems.

MATH 8550.title: Special Topics in Numerical Analysis
MATH 8550.description: Special topics in numerical analysis, including iterative methods for large linear systems, computer aided geometric design, multivariate splines, numerical solutions for pde's, numerical quadrature and cubature, numerical optimization, wavelet analysis for numerical imaging. In any semester, one of the above topics will be covered.

MATH 8600.title: Probability
MATH 8600.description: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectation and higher moments, conditional probability and expectation, convergence of sequences and series of random variables, strong and weak laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, infinitely divisible distributions, weak convergence of measures, central limit theorems.

MATH 8605.title: Problem Session in Probability
MATH 8605.description: Techniques and approaches to problems in probability as an aid to mastery of the basic theory.

MATH 8630.title: Stochastic Analysis
MATH 8630.description: Conditional expectation, Brownian motion, semimartingales, stochastic calculus, stochastic differential equations, stochastic control, stochastic filtering.

MATH 8710.title: Applied Mathematics: Variational Methods/Perturbation Theory
MATH 8710.description: Calculus of variations, Euler-Lagrange equations, Hamilton's principle, approximate methods, eigenvalue problems, asymptotic expansions, method of steepest descent, method of stationary phase, perturbation of eigenvalues, nonlinear eigenvalue problems, oscillations and periodic solutions, Hopf bifurcation, singular perturbation theory, applications.

MATH 8740.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 8740.description: Solutions of initial value problems: existence, uniqueness, and dependence on parameters, differential inequalities, maximal and minimal solutions, continuation of solutions, linear systems, self-adjoint eigenvalue problems, Floquet Theory.

MATH 8750.title: Introduction to Dynamical Systems
MATH 8750.description: Continuous dynamical systems, trajectories, periodic orbits, invariant sets, structure of alpha and omega limit sets, applications to two-dimensional autonomous systems of ODE's, Poincare-Bendixson Theorem, discrete dynamical systems, infinite dimensional spaces, semi-dynamical systems, functional differential equations.

MATH 8770.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 8770.description: Classification of second order linear partial differential equations, modern treatment of characteristics, function spaces, Sobolev spaces, Fourier transform of generalized functions, generalized and classical solutions, initial and boundary value problems, eigenvalue problems.

MATH 8800.title: Directed Reading and/or Projects
MATH 8800.description: Directed reading and/or project at the doctoral level.

MATH 8850.title: Directed Collaborative Research
MATH 8850.description: Research in a group setting on a topic of current interest in mathematics, under the direction of one or more faculty members. Emphasis will be given to problems that may be accessible to elementary methods. An introduction to basic research methods in mathematics, as well as expository and literature-search skills. Required for all first year graduate students.

MATH 8900.title: Seminar in Algebra
MATH 8900.description: A study of some phase of current research in algebra.

MATH 8910.title: Seminar in Analysis
MATH 8910.description: A study of some phase of current research in analysis.

MATH 8920.title: Seminar in Topology
MATH 8920.description: A study of some phase of current research in topology.

MATH 8930.title: Seminar in Algebraic Geometry
MATH 8930.description: A study of some phase of current research in algebraic geometry.

MATH 8940.title: Seminar in Number Theory
MATH 8940.description: A study of some phase of current research in number theory.

MATH 8950.title: Seminar in Numerical Analysis
MATH 8950.description: A study of some phase of current research in numerical analysis.

MATH 8960.title: Seminar in Probability
MATH 8960.description: A study of some phase of current research in probability.

MATH 8970.title: Seminar in Applied Mathematics
MATH 8970.description: A study of some phase of current research in applied mathematics.

MATH 8980.title: Seminar in Geometry
MATH 8980.description: A study of some phase of current research in geometry.

MATH 9000.title: Doctoral Research
MATH 9000.description: Research while enrolled for a doctoral degree under the direction of faculty members.

MATH 9005.title: Doctoral Graduate Student Seminar
MATH 9005.description: Advanced supervised experience in an applied setting. This course may not be used to satisfy a student's approved program of study.

MATH 9300.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MATH 9300.description: Dissertation writing under the direction of the major professor.
